data.title: azure-pipelines-tasks-azure-arm-rest-v2 - Part Name ".../OpenSSL License.txt" causes tfx create extension build break
data.body:
Question: Consuming "azure-pipelines-tasks-azure-arm-rest-v2" node library causes a build break when using "tfx create extension" to create azure task.

Would anyone know what I can do fix this?

Example:
tfx extension create --root <path>\_build --output-path <path>\_build --manifests <path>\_build\extension-manifest-bld.json --rev-version
TFS Cross Platform Command Line Interface v0.6.4
Copyright Microsoft Corporation
error: Error: Part Name '<path>/node_modules/azure-pipelines-tasks-azure-arm-rest-v2/openssl/OpenSSL License.txt' is invalid. Please check the following:
error: 1. No whitespace or any of these characters: #^[]<>?
error: 2. Cannot end with a period.
error: 3. No percent-encoded / or \ characters. Additionally, % must be followed by two hex characters.

All I did was to add the line
    "azure-pipelines-tasks-azure-arm-rest-v2": "^1.0.4",

to my package.json file and I get the build break from tfx.
Thanks for any advice.

data.title: Environment variable substitution failed in Configuration File (docker-compose.yml)
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Task Name**: Azure Web App for Containers Deploy

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines, Ubuntu:16.04
- Agent - Hosted or Private:  Hosted
   
## Issue Description
I have a pipeline with 3 tasks in it
1. Run a Docker-Compose (Command : Build)
2. Run a Docker-Compose (Command : Push)
3. Azure Web App on Container Deploy 

**Task 1 & 2** are linked with a docker-compose.prod.yml file that have variables that get substituted from a environment variable group (linked with the pipeline ofcourse)

**Task 3** in which I have linked the following Configuration File (to be updated/deployed on my multicontainers web service) :- 
Contents of Configuration File 
```
version: '3.7'

services:
  web:
    command: python3 manage.py runserver 0.0.0.0:8000
    image: "${AZ_CONTAINER_REGISTRY}/${APP1_IMAGE}:${APP1_VERSION}"
    ports:
      - 8000:8000
  app2:
    command: python app.py
    image: "${AZ_CONTAINER_REGISTRY}/${APP2_IMAGE}:${APP2_VERSION}"
    expose:
      - 8080
    restart: always
```

However, in Task 3 the variables DO NOT get substituted when the Task is performed. Task updates my multicontainer web service config as it is as shown above.

What confuses me that Task 1 and Task 2 are successfully performed i.e. the yml files linked to those DO get variables substituted from same variable group but Task 3 fail to do so before deploying it to web service.

Important to note that:
* All Variables (AZ_CONTAINER_REGISTRY, APP1_IMAGE, APP1_VERSION, APP2_IMAGE, APP2_VERSION) are NOT secret.

data.title: Feature Request: Support Multiple Database Targets in Task SQL Database Deployment

labels.name: environment:triage
labels.description: Issues need to be triage by environment-deployment team

data.body:
This task works great for deploying to a single database.  It would be even more awesome if it could be enhanced to support deploying the same dacpac to multiple databases.  

I understand we could do this now using "Each" loops in YAML or a custom PS task but it would be great if this pre-built task could accept a comma delimited list of DB names - limiting the functionality to deploying to multiple targets on the same server.

Thanks for considering.

data.title: nuget install task should work with any version
data.body:
The nuget install task should work with any version of nuget. It currently doesn't support the latest nuget.

https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.8.0-preview.2/nuget.exe

No one wants to be blocked from accomplishing their work, and I doubt the azure team wants to continuously update this task every time there is a new nuget version, so this should just work.

data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*:  FEATURE

**Enter Task Name**:  `Package and deploy Helm charts`

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?

Azure Pipelines
    
- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
Private.  Redhat 7.5

## Issue Description

Using Helm 3, it does not seem possible to run a `helm registry login` command in order to login to Azure Container Registry.  The error we get is:

```
2020-09-23T19:30:09.6325304Z [command]/builds/agent1/_tool/helm/3.3.0/x64/linux-amd64/helm registry login $(server) -u $(user) -p $(password)
2020-09-23T19:30:09.6407913Z ##[error]Error: unknown command "registry login" for "helm"
```

HELM_EXPERIMENTAL_OCI=1 is being set.

I see this:  https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/pull/13005

But don't see it as an available task option?

Are we not allowed to use ACR as a chart store for Helm charts?

data.body:

list here (V# not needed):

## Environment

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:

    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 

## Issue Description

[Include task name(s), screenshots and any other relevant details]

Helm 3.3.4 was released this morning and warnings are now being written to the error stream causing the task to fail. I logged an issue with helm here https://github.com/helm/helm/issues/8792, but they recommended that I log an issue with you.

bacongobbler commented 9 minutes ago • 
edited 
Please file an issue upstream with Azure DevOps. There's nothing we can do here. Helm is correctly reporting a security issue that the user should address. It is Azure DevOps that is handling the log output incorrectly.

An alternative option would be to fix the permissions of your kubeconfig file within the devops task. I assume this may also be set up by azure devops, which I would again urge you to file an issue there.

data.title: AzureResourceGroupDeploymentV2 - Escaping [ results in [[ after deployment.
data.body:
## Note  
Deploying an ARM template using this extension gives a different result than deploying the ARM template using Powershell or [Azure Portal](https://ms.portal.azure.com/#create/Microsoft.Template).

data.title: DotNetCoreCLIV2 push has no ability to skip duplicates
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLIV2  

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/DotNetCoreCLIV2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted
    
## Issue Description

A pipeline that tries to push a NuGet package can result in a 409 (Conflict) if the pipeline is run again with no change in the version number.

For example, if the following YAML is run more than once (with no project changes), all runs (except the first) result in an error:

```yaml
steps:
- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  inputs:
    command: 'pack'
    packagesToPack: '**/*.csproj'
    versioningScheme: 'off'

- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  continueOnError: true
  inputs:
    command: 'push'
    packagesToPush: '$(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)/*.nupkg'
    nuGetFeedType: 'internal'
    publishVstsFeed: 'XXXXXXXX'
```

> Pushing XXXX.1.0.0.nupkg to 'https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/'...
>   PUT https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/
>   Conflict https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/ 72ms
> To skip already published packages, use the option --skip-duplicate
> error: Response status code does not indicate success: 409 (Conflict - The feed already contains 'XXXX 1.0.0'. (DevOps Activity ID: CCA0F039-7739-4D8A-9B96-BC42DBCCEA1C)).

Per the error message, I need to set `--skip-duplicate`, but there is no way to set it. I tried adding an `arguments` value and inspected the source code, but I don't see any easy solutions.

### Error logs

> Pushing XXXX.1.0.0.nupkg to 'https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/'...
>   PUT https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/
>   Conflict https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/ 72ms
> To skip already published packages, use the option --skip-duplicate
> error: Response status code does not indicate success: 409 (Conflict - The feed already contains 'XXXX 1.0.0'. (DevOps Activity ID: CCA0F039-7739-4D8A-9B96-BC42DBCCEA1C)).

data.title: DownloadPipelineArtifact artifacts size is not precise enough
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: DownloadPipelineArtifact@2

## Environment

Azure Pipelines. MSRC-CCF. Agent version: 2.174.2
Agent: Hosted - ubuntu-18.04

## Issue Description

DownloadPipelineArtifact@2 logging includes size of downloaded artifacts. The size is only precise to the `0.1MB` so everything below `0.05MB` (assuming rounded to the closest digit) will be reported as `0.0MB`, which makes it looks like no artifact was effectively downloaded:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42961061/93897013-82c8d200-fce9-11ea-9cae-0dd087ba6ada.png)

Job: https://dev.azure.com/MSRC-CCF/CCF/_build/results?buildId=13022&view=logs&j=e2a2669a-638d-5159-fc94-d9196412c4a4&t=728b2fc9-b164-5bae-57f2-601e07337b91 

Instead, the size should be reported in `B` or `kB` for small artifacts, depending on their size.

data.title: Build fails because of incorrect Build.SourceBranch variable value
data.body:
*Type*: **Bug**

**Enter Task Name**: any task with condition using the `Build.SourceBranch` variable

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines (agent version: '2.174.2', image version: '20200827.1')

## Issue Description

The variable `Build.SourceBranch` is documented to have this format for Git repositories: `Git repo branch: refs/heads/master`. This format was changed in the latest Azure Pipeline build agent so our builds are failing now.

See documentation: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/build/variables?view=azure-devops&tabs=yaml

### Task logs

This is the condition we use in the **S3Upload@1** task:

```
- task: S3Upload@1
  condition: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/development'))
```

Here is the log from the **S3Upload@1** task which shows the format has changed:


```
Evaluating: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/development'))
Expanded: and(True, eq('development', 'refs/heads/development'))
Result: False
```

Second task:
```
Evaluating: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/master'))
Expanded: and(True, eq('development', 'refs/heads/master'))
Result: False
```


### Troubleshooting

This was working with agent version: '2.174.1', image version: '20200827.1'.

Builds from such agents show successful **S3Upload@1** and so the check was working correctly:

```
Starting: S3Upload
==============================================================================
Task         : Amazon S3 Upload
Description  : Upload file and folder content to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (S3) Bucket on AWS
Version      : 1.7.0
...
All uploads to S3 completed
Finishing: S3Upload
```

This log confirms the format of the `Build.SourceBranch` variable:

```
Evaluating: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/master'))
Expanded: and(True, eq('refs/heads/development', 'refs/heads/master'))
Result: False
```

data.title: FileTransform correctly applies all transforms but still reports Error Unable to apply transformation for the given package - Changes are already present in the package.
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: bug

**Enter Task Name**: FileTransform

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 
      - Account: PromontoryNetwork
      - TeamProject: newco.com
      - Definition: 2
      - Build Number: 0.2.18

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 

    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: **windows-latest**


## Issue Description

I have a multi-stage YAML pipeline, that has the following Filesystem Transform task defined in a Deployment Job:

```
- task: FileTransform@2
  displayName: 'Apply Release Transforms'
  inputs:
    folderPath: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)\$(artifactName)\deploy\'
    enableXmlTransform: true
    xmlTransformationRules: |
      -transform *.Release.config -xml *.config
      -transform *.$(Environment.Name).config -xml *.config
      -transform config\**\*.Release.config -xml config\**\*.config
      -transform config\**\*.$(Environment.Name).config -xml config\**\*.config
    xmlTargetFiles: |
      web.config
```

We have two configuration files in the root of the application that need at least the Release transform applied (web.config and ApplicationInsights.config) as well as optional environment transforms.
Similarly there are a number of .config files in the config folder, that have optional release and environment transforms.

Looking at the logs and the transformed files, all transforms are being correctly applied to the target files, but we are still getting the following error reported from the task (note that this is not stopping the deployment, but it is creating noise in the reports that makes it look like an error has occurred):

```
##[error]Unable to apply transformation for the given package - Changes are already present in the package.
```

### Task logs

[23.txt](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5261355/23.txt)

data.title: Environment Transforms are not being applied with AzureRmWebAppDeployment in YAML pipelines
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: AzureRmWebAppDeployment

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines?
        
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number:
      - Account: PromontoryNetwork
      - TeamProject: newco.com
      - Definition: 2
      - Build Number: 0.2.7

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: **windows-latest**

## Issue Description

I have a multi-stage YAML pipeline that I'd like to apply config transforms to my web application. The `*.Release.config` transforms are applied correctly, but I'm not seeing the environment transforms (such as `courier.Dev.config` or `web.Prod.config` being applied. The files are included in the deployment package.

The documentation is clearly confused as to the name used, with the [task documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/deploy/azure-rm-web-app-deployment?view=azure-devops#prerequisites-for-the-task) stating:

> The configuration transformations will be run for .Release.config and .{EnvironmentName}.config on the *.config files.

While the [File transforms and variable substitution reference documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/transforms-variable-substitution?view=azure-devops&tabs=Classic#configuration-transform-file-naming-conventions) states:

> XML transformation will be run on the *.config file for transformation configuration files named `*.Release.config` or `*.<stage>.config`

 A sample stage is configured as (with Stage, Environment and Deployment all with the same name):

```
- stage: Dev
  dependsOn: Build
  condition: succeeded()
  jobs:
  - deployment: Dev
    environment: "Dev"
    variables:
    - group: DevDeploy
    strategy:
      runOnce:
        deploy:
          steps:
          - task: ExtractFiles@1
            displayName: 'Extract files'
            inputs:
              archiveFilePatterns: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/$(artifactName)/$(artifactName).zip'
              cleanDestinationFolder: true
              destinationFolder: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)\$(artifactName)\deploy\'
          - task: qetza.replacetokens.replacetokens-task.replacetokens@3
            displayName: 'Replace tokens in **/*.config'
            inputs:
              rootDirectory: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)\$(artifactName)\deploy\'
              targetFiles: '**\*.config'
              tokenPrefix: '#{'
              tokenSuffix: '}'
          - task: AzureRmWebAppDeployment@4
            displayName: 'Deploy Azure App Service'
            inputs:
              azureSubscription: $(azureSubConnection)
              appType: webApp
              WebAppName: '$(WebApp)'
              packageForLinux: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)\$(artifactName)\deploy\'
              useWebDeploy: true
              deploymentType: webDeploy
              TakeAppOfflineFlag: false
              RemoveAdditionalFilesFlag: false
              ExcludeFilesFromAppDataFlag: false
              enableXmlTransform: true
              enableXmlVariableSubstitution: true
```

### Task logs

Logs for Dev Deployment attached.
[TaskLogs.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5255114/TaskLogs.zip)

## Troubleshooting

### Error logs

No errors are thrown.

`    - task: NuGetCommand@2

Looking at the logs Foo.nuspec creates a nupkg with a version like  1.1.0-feature0098.nupkg

Any ideas what is causing this?

data.title: Add traffic weighting to AzureAppServiceManageV0
data.body:
## Required Information

*Type*: Feature
**Enter Task Name**: AzureAppServiceManageV0

## Issue Description

Currently the App Service Manage task supports swapping slots. It would be nice if it also supported configuring the traffic weight between different slots (see https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/app-service/deploy-staging-slots#route-traffic). Right now to accomplish the same thing you have to use a CLI task and know the appropriate command (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/webapp/traffic-routing?view=azure-cli-latest).

This change would allow for easier handling of advanced deployment strategies like canary deployments.

data.title: Kubernetes Manifest Task - Create Secret Action - secretArguments is not exactly multiline
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: Kubernetes Manifest Task  

## Environment
Azure Pipelines

Account Name: `sifter`
Project Name: `musical-guide`
Build Number: `20200915.11`

- Agent - Hosted
agent queue name: `Azure Pipelines`

## Issue Description

I'm trying to use the **Create Secret** Action of the **Kubernetes Manifest** task. The docs say that the `secretArguments` field is multi-line, however...

The following results in `error: exactly one NAME is required, got 3`. No secret is created.
```
--from-literal=KEY1=VAL1 \
--from-literal=KEY2=VAL2 \
--from-literal=KEY3=VAL3 \
```

And the following, with backslashes removed, gives `error: exactly one NAME is required, got 2`. No secret is created, but the error message is listing fewer NAMES (2 instead of 3)
```
--from-literal=KEY1=VAL1 
--from-literal=KEY2=VAL2 
--from-literal=KEY3=VAL3 
```

Here's the **_REALLY_** weird stuff
The following creates a secret correctly with 3 keys in it.
```
--from-literal=KEY1=VAL1 --from-literal=KEY2=VAL2 
--from-literal=KEY3=VAL3
```

But the following fails with `error: exactly one NAME is required, got 2`
```
--from-literal=KEY1=VAL1 --from-literal=KEY2=VAL2 
--from-literal=KEY3=VAL3 
--from-literal=KEY4=VAL4
```

Extra Notes:
- I tried various combinations of `trailing spaces/no trailing spaces/backslashes` and none of it worked in a predictable way.
- All of the above works when I run it locally

### Task logs

[logs_2654.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5228022/logs_2654.zip)


### Error logs

`error: exactly one NAME is required, got 2`

data.title: The PFX file you are trying to import requires either a different password or membership in an Active Directory principal to which it is protected
data.body:
I am using Azure key vault task to download a certificate from KV and then install it in the build agent. I eventually want to execute some functional tests that need this certificate to authenticate.

This is my inline powershell after downloading the certificate in the previous task


param(
 [Parameter(Mandatory=$True)]
 [string]
 $firstpartypwd
)
$securePassword=ConvertTo-SecureString $firstpartypwd –asplaintext –force
$kvSecretBytes = [System.Convert]::FromBase64String("$(firstpartycert)")
$certCollection = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2Collection
$certCollection.Import($kvSecretBytes,'',[System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509KeyStorageFlags]::Exportable)
$protectedCertificateBytes = $certCollection.Export([System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ContentType]::Pkcs12, $securePassword)
$pfxPath = [Environment]::GetFolderPath("Desktop") + "\<some cert>.pfx"
[System.IO.File]::WriteAllBytes($pfxPath, $protectedCertificateBytes)
Import-PfxCertificate -FilePath  $pfxPath -CertStoreLocation Cert:\LocalMachine\Root -Password $securePassword

I get this error:
The PFX file you are trying to import requires either a different password or membership in an Active Directory principal to which it is protected

Is any property missing on the downloaded certificate? Shall I change anything in the script to be able to install it on the hosted build agent?

data.title: AzureCLI@2 task running az webapp create-remote-connection hangs ubuntu agent due to child processes not terminating
data.body:
## Required Information

**Type**: Bug or Feature (?)

**Task Name**: AzureCLI@2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted - ubuntu

## Issue Description

AzureCLI@2 and `az webapp create-remote-connection`
 
There appears to be pitfalls in attempting to establish the SSH SCM bridge connection in context of an Azure CLI agent task with obvious solutions not forthcoming.

`az webapp create-remote-connection` in `bash` with either `&` (background task) or in `pwsh/pscore` `Start-Process` will just hang the task waiting for child processes to exit - and unless you're familiar with the agent's underlying process model, you're in for a nightmare ride.

It is not obvious to me how `az webapp ssh` is best used as it doesn't appear to behave the same as just `ssh`. I imagine it is just for opening an interactive shell session ([`webapp ssh`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/webapp?view=azure-cli-latest#az_webapp_ssh)) and the other is just for a background tcp tunnel ([`webapp create-remote-connection`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/webapp?view=azure-cli-latest#az_webapp_create_remote_connection)). 

> Note: Not to be confused with [`remote-connection create`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/ext/webapp/webapp/remote-connection?view=azure-cli-latest) which also lurks in the 'extension reference' documentation.

This is primarily a usability concern - if attempting SSH connections using this tool and with this task (which is reasonable given its purpose), the resulting processes spawned `az` does not appear to sit well with how the task is managing its process groups on the agent. 

Without using `setsid`, or `pgrep`ing for, in this instance, "webapp", you cannot reliably terminate all the spawned processes. The spawned process which hangs the agent appears to possibly be `python3`.

Such issues could be circumvented if, say, [Add task to run bash scripts on App Service slots](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11441) were adopted.

Is it the responsibility of this task to better manage the parent process group, such that it doesn't hang the agent on finalizing the task? 

Is there a recommended approach worth documenting for working with these types of commands in the context of `AzureCLI@2` ? 

Could this task be improved with some task options regarding the process model?

## Troubleshooting
I used the following inline bash script to troubleshoot what was going on, after the calls to `az webapp create-remote-connection`, to query _what jobs and processes were actually running_ at various stages, with the intention of running just a dummy `helloworld.sh` on a target app service (being a custom docker container that has had [SSH enabled as per documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/app-service/configure-custom-container#enable-ssh), and that it has a custom ssh `id_agent.pub` key in its list of `authorized_keys` for `root`, to enable _passwordless_ ssh scripting):

```
shopt
echo Initial processes
ps ax --forest -O pgid,tpgid
curl https://___appservicename___.azurewebsites.net/robots123345.txt
chmod 600 deploy/docker/id_agent
setsid sh -c "az webapp create-remote-connection -n ___appservicename___ -g ___resourcegroup___ -p 2222" &
sleep 30s
mkdir ~/.ssh
chmod 700 ~/.ssh
ssh-keyscan -4 -p 2222 -t rsa localhost >> ~/.ssh/known_hosts
chmod 644 ~/.ssh/known_hosts
ssh -T -l root -i deploy/docker/id_agent -p 2222 localhost < deploy/scripts/helloworld.sh
echo Before killing all webapp processes
ps ax --forest -O pgid,tpgid
jobs
jobs -p
kill -- -$(jobs -p)
sleep 10s
echo After kill by PGID webapp processes
ps ax --forest -O pgid,tpgid
jobs
jobs -p
```

## Workaround

Execute the command **`kill -- -$(jobs -p)`** which `SIGTERM`s the processes in the process group of the started background job. 

I also had success with `kill $(pgrep -f webapp)` before I analyzed the process group behaviour and decided to call instead `setsid`. This seems to be the best solution for Powershell Core also as I could not find cmdlets that dealt with process groups.

Others have worked around using [`expect`](https://github.com/projectkudu/kudu/issues/3041#issuecomment-559796949).

### Error logs

I hope these error logs may help people trace similar issues they may suffer.

Without the workaround, the task would be stuck at 100%, and never finishing, with the final log entry of note being being either: 

```
The STDIO streams did not close within 10 seconds of the exit event from process '/usr/bin/pwsh'. This may indicate a child process inherited the STDIO streams and has not yet exited.
```

``` 
The STDIO streams did not close within 10 seconds of the exit event from process '/bin/bash'. This may indicate a child process inherited the STDIO streams and has not yet exited.
```

### Task logs

Here is the agent's process stack at various stages:

### Before `create-remote-connection`:
```
   PID   PGID  TPGID S TTY          TIME COMMAND
....
  1407   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:01 /opt/vsts/provisioner/provisioner
  2802   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:02  \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/bin/Agent.Listener run
  2843   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:04      \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/bin/Agent.Worker spawnclient 116 119
  3400   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:00          \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/externals/node/bin/node /home/vsts/work/_tasks/AzureCLI_46e4be58-730b-4389-8a2f-ea10b3e5e815/2.0.16/azureclitask.js
  3460   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:00              \_ /bin/bash /home/vsts/work/_temp/azureclitaskscript1600125574374.sh
  3461   1407     -1 R ?        00:00:00                  \_ ps ax --forest -O pgid,tpgid
```

### After `create-remote-connection` - this is with setsid. Without setsid, the PGID would have been `1407` and there would have been no wrapping `sh` process:
```
   PID   PGID  TPGID S TTY          TIME COMMAND
....
  1407   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:02 /opt/vsts/provisioner/provisioner
  2802   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:02  \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/bin/Agent.Listener run
  2843   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:05      \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/bin/Agent.Worker spawnclient 116 119
  3400   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:00          \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/externals/node/bin/node /home/vsts/work/_tasks/AzureCLI_46e4be58-730b-4389-8a2f-ea10b3e5e815/2.0.16/azureclitask.js
  3460   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:00              \_ /bin/bash /home/vsts/work/_temp/azureclitaskscript1600125574374.sh
  3535   3535     -1 S ?        00:00:00                  \_ sh -c az webapp create-remote-connection -n ___appservicename___ -g ___resourcegroup____ -p 2222
  3537   3535     -1 S ?        00:00:00                  |   \_ bash /usr/bin/az webapp create-remote-connection -n ___appservicename___ -g ___resourcegroup____ -p 2222
  3538   3535     -1 S ?        00:00:01                  |       \_ /opt/az/bin/python3 -Im azure.cli webapp create-remote-connection -n ___appservicename___ -g ___resourcegroup____ -p 2222
  3582   1407     -1 R ?        00:00:00                  \_ ps ax --forest -O pgid,tpgid

since 1st of September 2020 we are facing nuget push upload error on every try in certain package in our on-premise agent which is pushing/uploading to Azure DevOps services project feed.

data.title: VSTest Task unable to find custom test logger when testSelector: testPlan
data.body:
**Problem**

I have written a custom logger to log test results in a kusto database. I added the loggers friendly name to my runsettings file like:

`<Logger friendlyName="KustoTestLogger" />`

The assembly of the test logger is located in the same folder as the test container .dll is.

When executing tests via the VSTest task and settng the **testSelector: testAssemblies**, everything works fine, the logger gets executed. 

However, when settings **testSelector: testPlan**, the task fails to find the test selector:

> 2020-09-14T08:51:28.0307526Z ##[debug]ProxyDiscoveryRequest: HandleLogMessage Entered
2020-09-14T08:51:28.0410963Z ##[error]DiscoveryMessage : Microsoft.VisualStudio.TestPlatform.Common.Exceptions.InvalidLoggerException: Could not find a test logger with AssemblyQualifiedName, URI or FriendlyName 'KustoTestLogger'.
2020-09-14T08:51:28.0427960Z ##[debug]Processed: ##vso[task.logissue type=error;]DiscoveryMessage : Microsoft.VisualStudio.TestPlatform.Common.Exceptions.InvalidLoggerException: Could not find a test logger with AssemblyQualifiedName, URI or FriendlyName 'KustoTestLogger'.
2020-09-14T08:51:28.0431675Z    at Microsoft.VisualStudio.TestPlatform.CrossPlatEngine.Client.TestLoggerManager.Initialize(String runSettings)
2020-09-14T08:51:28.0432367Z    at Microsoft.VisualStudio.TestPlatform.Client.TestPlatform.CreateDiscoveryRequest(IRequestData requestData, DiscoveryCriteria discoveryCriteria, TestPlatformOptions options)
2020-09-14T08:51:28.0433451Z    at Microsoft.VisualStudio.TestPlatform.CommandLine.TestPlatformHelpers.TestRequestManager.DiscoverTests(DiscoveryRequestPayload discoveryPayload, ITestDiscoveryEventsRegistrar discoveryEventsRegistrar, ProtocolConfig protocolConfig)
2020-09-14T08:51:28.0434203Z    at Microsoft.VisualStudio.TestPlatform.Client.DesignMode.DesignModeClient.<>c__DisplayClass24_0.<StartDiscovery>b__0()
2020-09-14T08:51:28.0434876Z ##[debug]ProxyDiscoveryRequest: HandleDiscoveryComplete Entered
2020-09-14T08:51:28.0435330Z ##[debug]ProxyDiscoveryRequest: Dispose Entered
2020-09-14T08:51:28.0435743Z ##[debug]ProxyDiscoveryRequest: Abort Entered

I tried to also set the custom adapter path but this didnt fix the issue (however since the logger is located at the same place as the test container, this shouldn't be required).

I have had a look into your code in this repo, however I am at the point DTAExecutionHost gets called (I couldn't find the source code of this one). Everything looks good so far and I couldn't find the issue, so I am guessing there is maybe something wrong in the execution host?

Or is it not possible to add a custom logger when executing tests with testSelector: testPlan? Do I have to add another custom adapter path?

I execute the tests as container job btw.

**Expected behavior**
I can set the custom logger in the .runsettings file. VSTest task takes the custom logger (as well as the default trx logger) and uses it during test execution. I do not need to add any additional test adapter path if the path to the test logger is the same as the path to the test container.

**Current behavior**
Custom test logger is not found when added to .runsettings file. Tests won't get executed.

data.title: task.setvariable changes variable casing
data.body:
Related: https://github.com/actions/virtual-environments/issues/1578

## Description
Azure DevOps sets NPM_CONFIG_CACHE (all uppercase). Some tools like yarn/node, they manage to add a lowercase version of some npm variables (npm_config_cache for example) by directly setting it in an environment block when calling CreateProcess. This breaks some tools when they encounter duplicate variables in their environment block, like msbuild/CL.exe.

I've submitted a fix to the script that sets up the uppercase variable https://github.com/actions/virtual-environments/issues/1578 .
To work around the problem in the meantime, I added a task in my pipeline to reset the NPM_CONFIG_CACHE variable and then reset it as npm_config_cache:
Write-Host "##vso[task.setvariable variable=npm_config_cache]$npm_config_cache"

However it seems like ##vso[task.setvariable] always sets the variable in uppercase. This is a problem because it makes it impossible for anyone to work around the duplicate env variable problem.

Area for Triage: Scripting and command line

Question, Bug, or Feature?: Bug


## Expected behavior
task.setvariable does not alter the casing of env variables

## Actual behavior
task.setvariable uses the uppercase version of a variable's name

## Repro steps
```yaml
  - task: PowerShell@2
    displayName: Reset NPM_CONFIG_CACHE
    inputs:
      targetType: "inline"
      script: Write-Host "##vso[task.setvariable variable=lowercase_variable]some value"
  - task: PowerShell@2
    displayName: Display env
    inputs:
      targetType: "inline"
      script:  gci env:* | sort-object name
```

And notice that the variable shown is LOWERCASE_VARIABLE instead of lowercase_variable.

data.title: Feature Request: IIS Web App Deployment deploy to new folder
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroupV0

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
    
- Agent - Private: Windows 2016 Datacenter, agent v2.174.1

## Feature Description

The "IIS Web App Deploy" task should limit downtime during the deployment by having a feature to extract and transform to a new folder, then update IIS to the new folder. A further option is to not extract/transform if the destination folder already exists.

Benefits:
1) The web site will only be down for the time of an application recycle
2) The previous version is preserved for easy rollback
3) Deploying a previous version will be faster, as extraction and transformation is skipped

*Example* new yaml inputs:

```
- task: IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup@0
  inputs:
    PhysicalPathForApplication: C:\inetpub\wwwroot\$(Build.DefinitionName)\$(Build.BuildNumber)
    SkipExtractionIfPathExists: true
```
```
- task: IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup@0
  inputs:
    # Relative to current IIS path
    PhysicalPathForApplication: ..\$(Build.BuildNumber)
    SkipExtractionIfPathExists: true
```

data.title: NugetCommand@2 versioningScheme: byBuildNumber truncates a build number with a hyphen
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.
*Type*: Bug
**Enter Task Name**: NugetCommand@2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines 
https://dev.azure.com/DenverHealth-EpicCogito/Epic/_build/results?buildId=34892&view=results

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
Hosted: windows-latest    

## Issue Description

I tried to use the built in versioning scheme functionality in NugetCommand@2's pack functionality with the following yaml
```
- task: NuGetCommand@2
  displayName: Nuget Pack
  inputs:
    command: 'pack'
    packagesToPack: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/b/dbatools.nuspec'
    versioningScheme: 'byBuildNumber'
```

I configured my build number using this yaml:
    name: 1.0.116-D$(BuildID)

Unfortunately, the version on the package is 1.0.116 :( 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16762974/92091986-bbcaf200-ed8e-11ea-9925-d099173966e8.png)

When I used the byPreReleaseNumber functionality it worked:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16762974/92092169-fc2a7000-ed8e-11ea-97cd-4bedf9ae660c.png)

I am unable to use the build date functionality because [PowerShell only allows you to have one hyphen](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/gallery/concepts/module-prerelease-support?view=powershell-7) in a pre-release package.

### Task logs

[logs_34892.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5167294/logs_34892.zip)

data.title: PublishSymbols fails after Windows Update
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**: Bug
**Enter Task Name**: PublishSymbols

## Environment
- Azure DevOps Server (on-premises) Version Dev17.M153.5
- private Agent
  - on Windows Server 2019 Version 1809
  - agent version 2.170.0
  - 5 agents are identically configured to the same pool

## Issue Description

The builds using PublishSymbols task were running fine until installation Windows updates.
Now the step fails with `Encountered Win32 error '203' from method 'SymEnumSourceFiles'`.

- We are using V1 and V2 of Publish symbols.
- Last successful run around 5th august.
- Windows updates installed on 13th august: KB4570505, KB4565349, KB4566424

Similar issues exist but already closed without helpful information:
- #9139 => x64 version on x64 Windows is installed
- #13439 => self-closed after downgrade to Win2016

Please note, the waning on dbghelp.dll is very confusing because expected and actual path are identical!

### Task logs

[1_Initialize Job.txt](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5155997/1_Initialize.Job.txt)
[14_Publish symbols.txt](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5155986/14_Publish.symbols.txt)

### Error logs

```
##[warning]Library dbghelp.dll is already loaded from an unexpected path. Expected 'C:\build\_work\_tasks\PublishSymbols_0675668a-7bba-4ccb-901d-5ad6554ca653\2.0.16\dbghelp.dll'. Actual 'C:\build\_work\_tasks\PublishSymbols_0675668a-7bba-4ccb-901d-5ad6554ca653\2.0.16\dbghelp.dll'.
##[error]Encountered Win32 error '203' from method 'SymEnumSourceFiles'.
```

data.title: CopyFilesOverSSHV0 0.174 adds on a network target path an additional ./ which then fails the build

labels.name: awaiting deployment
labels.description: Related changes are waiting for deployment to be completed

data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: CopyFilesOverSSHV0

list here (V0.174 not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/CopyFilesOverSSHV0

## Environment
Azure Pipelines

Agent - Private: 
Agent on MacOs Copy Files to a Windows Machine (Network Path).   
    
## Issue Description

With Update 0.174 it added an additional ./ in front of the Target Path which caused the Build to fail 

### Task logs

0.172
Working:
Copying file 

[Path of Ipa File] to \\\\[Network Path] on remote machine.

0.174
Not Working:
[Path of Ipa File] to ./\\\\[Network Path] on remote machine.

### Checkin causing change
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/commit/872607391d8e3242c2e7cbd3580b2eab0da95196#diff-4c4cee916c8efc058426c4fb2a742ccf

Tasks/CopyFilesOverSSHV0/copyfilesoverssh.ts 
Change from:
```
const targetPath = path.posix.join(targetFolder, relativePath);
```

To:
```
let targetPath = path.posix.join(targetFolder, relativePath);

if (!path.isAbsolute(targetPath)) {
         targetPath = `./${targetPath}`;
}
```
the path.IsAbsolute will say false because it is a windows Path with \\\\ instead of / like for unix

data.title: Resurrect deprecated SourceFolder parameter
data.body:
**Task name**: PublishSymbolsV2

**Description**: The PublishSymbols task assumes that the source files referenced by the pdb are rooted under Build.SourcesDirectory. It does not index source files unless they are under that directory. If a user synced and built from a different path, they will not be able to use this task to index their source. This change addresses that issue by introducing a new optional parameter to the task that defines the source directory. If unspecified, it defaults to using Build.SourcesDirectory (the current behavior). When I began the process of introducing the parameter, I found logic related to an old, deprecated parameter named SourceFolder. This seems to be exactly what I want to introduce, so I reused that name and removed the logic that warned of the parameter being deprecated.

**Documentation changes required:** (Y/N) Yes. Label and help strings for the new task parameter are needed.

**Added unit tests:** (Y/N) No new unit tests were created.

**Attached related issue:** (Y/N) <Please add link to related issue here>

**Checklist**:
- [x] Task version was bumped - please check [instruction](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/docs/taskversionbumping.md) how to do it
- [ ] Checked that applied changes work as expected

data.title: Allow custom environment name for IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroupV0 XDT transforms
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup

## Issue Description

We have a complex build pipeline that requires us to provide descriptive names for the different stages in order to differentiate between different web projects being deployed side-by-side independent of each other. Because of this, the use of Release.EnvironmentName to get the XML transform files in webdeployment-common-v2/fileTransformationsUtility.ts used by IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup is problematic for us. Right now we're using `##vso[task.setvariable]` to change the value of Release.EnvironmentName in the stages where we use the task, but since Release.* variables are supposed to be read-only, it's only a matter of time before this stops working.

We would like to be able to provide the environment name directly as a parameter to the task and to `fileTransformations()` in webdeployment-common-v2/fileTransformationsUtility.ts, and have it only use Release.EnvironmentName when that parameter is not explicitly set.

### Task logs

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]

## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

### Error logs

[Insert error from the logs here for a quick overview]

data.title: InstallAppleCertificateV2 and InstallAppleProvisioningProfileV1 often fails to download secure files

labels.name: awaiting deployment
labels.description: Related changes are waiting for deployment to be completed

data.body:
## Required Information


**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  Bug

**Task Name**: InstallAppleCertificateV2 and InstallAppleProvisioningProfileV1

## Environment
- Azure pipelines
- Hosted MacOS images

## Issue Description

These tasks are used to download secure files from Azure DevOps to VM during build. We have noticed that these tasks are unstable and often fail randomly (see errors below) and pass on retry.
Context: We run builds that contains a lot of jobs (~about 32 jobs) to validate Hosted images quality. Pass rate of this build is ~60%. In every second build, at least one job from 32 fails (about 2% of total number of jobs fail with issue for us). It produces a lot of noise.

### Task logs
InstallAppleCertificateV2:
```
##[error]Error: Invalid Resource
```
InstallAppleProvisioningProfileV1:
```
##[error]Error: connect ETIMEDOUT 13.107.42.18:443
```

Example of failed builds: 
- [Link 1](https://buildcanary.visualstudio.com/PipelineCanary/_build/results?buildId=1045786&view=logs&j=5439f50a-355e-5e3b-53c8-8a2ab2b00259&t=c7c268c4-17d9-444d-bfe7-74a313fc6244)
- [Link 2](https://buildcanary.visualstudio.com/PipelineCanary/_build/results?buildId=1039380&view=logs&j=5d6d3fdb-1da0-5537-bdfc-899d7af9b662&t=e8bd860f-623a-4df5-9359-9bea80e16d4f)
- [Link 3](https://buildcanary.visualstudio.com/PipelineCanary/_build/results?buildId=1038886&view=logs&j=bf815176-2569-5c26-3bfb-e1028de577da&t=9ff99e64-7306-4a0b-93d8-d9f7be140056)

## Possible solution
I propose implementation of retry logic on task level. So if downloading fails, wait a few seconds and try one more time.

data.title: Cache: Allow writing to existing caches
data.body:
**Task name**: Cache

**Description**: Added immutable input

**Documentation changes required:**  Y

**Added unit tests:** N

**Attached related issue:**

**Checklist**:
- [x] Task version was bumped - please check [instruction](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/docs/taskversionbumping.md) how to do it
- [ ] Checked that applied changes work as expected

I've been needing this for a long time, really since the Cache task was still in beta. I've been looking through the issues and the docs, and I've concluded that this kind of functionality really needs to be here, in a dedicated form.

The docs compare and contrast Artifacts with Caching, saying Artifacts are for necessary outputs from one stage/pipeline to another, and Caching is for dependencies which might be acquirable elsewhere. It seems to me there is a third type, and that is actual file caching of compiled output.

In looking around, I saw [this comment](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/10842#issuecomment-510637798) which mentions a "rolling" cache idea, but the poster seems to be out-thinking themselves with regards to the keys. Most build systems (e.g. make, msbuild, etc) already check for outdated output and do incremental recompiling. I see no need for any kind of commit sha checking. Simply allow users to save the data, and let the build systems handl the rest.

I also saw an aside about security concerns. I can't really imagine how or why that's an issue, but at least by adding an input that is defaulted to read-only, there shouldn't be any worries about issues popping up for various pipelines.

Let me do my best to emphasize that this is desperately needed. Build times are absurd without caching. I wish msbuild had a more robust solution than what it has now, but we can't even use that without a mutable cache. The fallback key system is too clumsy, and it can lead to odd behavior (if we write to a specific key, and read from a general key, then we have to import all previous caches. If those caches have the same files, which files wind up being used?).

Please give this PR some consideration, I would really appreciate it.

p.s. I was unable to build either side of this, so it isn't tested. If it is wildly wrong, I will gladly work to get it right.

Cross PR: https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-agent/pull/3090

data.title: AzureFunctionApp if deploying to a slot with auto-swap which fails, task returns successful
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: AzureFunctionAppV1 

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureFunctionAppV1

## Environment
- Azure Pipelines 

- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

When you deploy to a function app `staging` slot that has auto-swap enabled, if that auto swap operation fails, the AzureFunctionAppV1 task either doesn't know or doesn't wait to see if auto-swap was successful and so the task returns green / successful event where a slot-swap failed. This should throw an error and stop the pipeline run if this errors.

## Troubleshooting
- configure a function app with a staging slot that has auto-swap enabled.
- configure the staging slot with the follow app settings based on a function called `healthcheck` that just returns 200:
`-WEBSITE_SWAP_WARMUP_PING_PATH /healthcheck -WEBSITE_SWAP_WARMUP_PING_STATUSES 500'`
The above `WEBSITE_SWAP_WARMUP_PING_STATUSES 500` will force a auto-swap to fail.
- Run a deployment to the `staging` slot using YAML or classic and observe the slots swap fail in Azure Activity Log initiated by the `SlotSwapJobProcessor` and also observe the pipeline task succeed and go green which is should not do.

data.title: Bug: Deployment Job: Stage cross output variable not possible when the deployment job is the first job in the stage.
data.body:
## Bug
```
jobs:
- deployment
  variables:
    octopusVersion: $[ stageDependencies.Build.Build.outputs['SetVersionInformation.OctopusVersion'] ]
```

The output variable from the Build stage can't be used when the deployment job is the first one in the stage. When a different (not deployment) job is running and using the same stageDependency then the deployment can work with the variable.

## Environment
- Azure Pipelines - Executed on On Premis agent.

Only the deployment job is executed on internal agent to contact the deployment platform.
```
Starting: Initialize job
Agent name: '********-Azure-Agent01'
Agent machine name: '**********'
Current agent version: '2.165.0'
Agent running as: '***********'
Prepare build directory.
Set build variables.
Download all required tasks.
Start tracking orphan processes.
Finishing: Initialize job
```

## Issue Description

We have integrated the new functionality to use output variables cross stages. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/release-notes/2020/pipelines/sprint-168-update#jobs-can-access-output-variables-from-previous-stages

The functionality is great and works fine. But during optimisation of the pipeline we refactored and optimised.
- Before stages overview: Build - Package&Deploy (Approval)
- Current stages overview: Build - Package - Deploy (Approval)

With the current setup the "deployment" job is the frist job in the Deploy stage. The tasks in the deployment job need to know the version number that has been build to deploy it. We transfer the variable via a output task variable that is reused in the Package stage and later in the Deploy stage.

But the deployment job is passing the variable from the build stage. Even if the variable is defined on the stage, scoping on the stage. The variable is always empty.

data.title: Syntax error in JSON for Azure IoT Edge "Push module images"
data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: AzureIoTEdgeV2

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises? Azure Pipelines
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:

    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 

## Issue Description

When trying to setup the "Push module images" action of the task, the `azureContainerRegistry` parameter needs to be specified as a valid JSON object. This is undocumented and leads to a very hard to debug error in the log, where the only failure is:

```##[error]SyntaxError: Unexpected token a in JSON at position 0```

After finding issue #13261 this helped me to find the root cause.

### Task logs

Can be provided on request but this is the relevant snippet, redacted:

```
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2062925Z Pushing module images...
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2065233Z ##[debug]containerregistrytype=Azure Container Registry
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2077212Z ##[debug]containerregistrytype=Azure Container Registry
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2078416Z ##[debug]azureSubscriptionEndpoint=<subscription_guid>
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2079480Z ##[debug]azureContainerRegistry=aregistryname.azurecr.io
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2100083Z ##[debug]task result: Failed
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2136264Z ##[error]SyntaxError: Unexpected token a in JSON at position 0
```

Note that the "unexpected token" is "a" which matches the first character of the name of the azureContainerRegistry.

## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

### Error logs

See Task logs above.

## Suggested fixes

After figuring out where the problem actually was, setting the `azureContainerRegistry` parameter correctly was done like this:

```
azureContainerRegistry: '{"loginServer":"$(azureContainerRegistry)", "id":"/subscriptions/<subscription_name>"}'
```

Please at least fix the documentation so that this is apparent. The current version at

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/azure-iot-edge?view=azure-devops#container-registry-types

strongly suggests that only the DNS name is enough.

Next up I don't see why this needs to be a JSON object including once again the subscription, seeing as that is specified as a separate parameter. Would be better to accept the DNS name in my opinion.

data.title: JSON substitution is case sensitive by default, and also does not log missed keys that match apart from case
data.body:
This is somewhat similar to the issue below, but my point is more of a difference in design opinion than a bug:
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/6656

Relevant code to the best of my knowledge, or in the general vicinity:
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/a6f349070b6ed807a134974af44e49cf262b8037/Tasks/Common/webdeployment-common-v2/jsonvariablesubstitutionutility.ts#L71

Comment from 6656 that I have found to be true:
'JSON variable substitutions are case-sensitive. Ensure that the casing provided in the variable and appsettings.json are same.'

First, I disagree with this decision as a default.  I can't think of many, if any, cases where I would want to differentiate two json elements by case within the same level.  True, JSON _is_ case sensitive and it does allow for two keys to be differentiated at the same level based on case.  But is this really something a user would ever intend to do?  Perhaps, but probably not.  Which thus leads me to my next point.

If case sensitive vars are unlikely to be intentional, the default should be case insensitive with case sensitive as an override option.  However, this is a breaking change and so on.  If we don't agree here, a log statement would help quite a bit to mitigate this.  "The following pattern was matched, but JSON variable substitution is case sensitive.  Skipping this key."

One could arguably blame the user for making the case mistake, but I would offer the counterpoint that good UX / DX design should strive to match intent of the user and warn them when there may be a mismatch between intent and results.

Thanks,
Travis

data.title: ExtractFiles incorrectly finds archives recursively

labels.name: awaiting deployment
labels.description: Related changes are waiting for deployment to be completed

data.body:
## Required Information

*Type*: Bug

*Task Name*: ExtractFiles


## Environment

*Server*: Azure Pipelines
- Account name: wencorepo
- Team project name: Dependencies
- Build number: 34933
- Pipeline: libzmq (definitionId=20)

From log:
- Agent name: 'Azure Pipelines 2'
- Agent machine name: 'fv-az246'
- Current agent version: '2.173.0'
- Operating System: Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS
- Virtual Environment: ubuntu-18.04 20200806.0
- Agent running as: 'vsts'


## Issue Description

The ExtractFiles task incorrectly extracts an archive (.tar.xz) that is nested under a subdirectory, even though we did not use a globstar (**) pattern in archiveFilePatterns.

It looks like `minimatch.match()` (extractfilestask.ts ln 87) is incorrectly matching files in subdirectories.
```js
var matched = minimatch.match(allFiles, parseResult.search, matchOptions);
```

This behavior occurs regardless of whether archiveFilePatterns is `'*.tar.xz'` or `'$(Build.SourcesDirectory)/*.tar.xz'`. It is a 100% repro.

I think it must be something about the minimatch version or its usage within Azure. I cannot reproduce the issue with a standalone copy of latest minimatch from npm.

Task definition:
```yaml
  - task: ExtractFiles@1
    displayName: Extract dependencies
    inputs:
      archiveFilePatterns: '$(Build.SourcesDirectory)/*.tar.xz'
      destinationFolder: '$(Build.SourcesDirectory)'
      cleanDestinationFolder: false
```

Pipeline details:
- Run: #20200812.4
- Job: Linux_owa4x
- Task: 'Extract dependencies'


### Task logs

Full debug log: [ExtractFiles-debug-log.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5082526/ExtractFiles-debug-log.zip)


### Error logs

This part of the log illustrates the issue. Notice there is no globstar (**) but it still finds recursively:

```text
##[debug]using: 1 archiveFilePatterns: /home/vsts/work/1/s/*.tar.xz to search for archives.
##[debug]searching for archives, pattern[0]: /home/vsts/work/1/s/*.tar.xz

Searching for: *.tar.xz under directory: /home/vsts/work/1/s/
##[debug]findPath: '/home/vsts/work/1/s/'
...
##[debug]11981 results
##[debug]Candidates found for match: 11981
##[debug]adding file: /home/vsts/work/1/s/depends/owasys_owa4x/gcc-linaro-5.3-2016.02-x86_64_arm-linux-gnueabihf.tar.xz
##[debug]adding file: /home/vsts/work/1/s/libsodium-1.0.18-linux-owa4x.tar.xz
Found: 2 files to extract:
/home/vsts/work/1/s/depends/owasys_owa4x/gcc-linaro-5.3-2016.02-x86_64_arm-linux-gnueabihf.tar.xz
/home/vsts/work/1/s/libsodium-1.0.18-linux-owa4x.tar.xz
```

## Issue Description

The slot being deployed to is using runtime version 3.0.14120.0 on Linux on EP1. It's not using Docker at all.

agent version: 2.164.8
OS: linux x64

## Issue Description

When I use the Docker@2 task to push docker images, it seems like it always pushs all layers, even thoguh the layers already exist in the registry.

I compared the Docker@2task with a manual call to "docker push" using a bash task. The bash task detected that all layers already exist on the server and completed in less than 1 second. The Docker@2 push task ran 52 seconds.

```yaml
  - bash: |
        docker login -u $(USER) -p $(PASSWORD) $(DOCKER_REGISTRY)
        docker push $(DOCKER_REGISTRY)/$(repository):$(version)-$(hash)
    displayName: Push docker image (app) - without Azrue DevOps task

  - task: Docker@2
    displayName: Push docker image (app)
    condition: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['publish'], true))
    inputs:
      containerRegistry: Harbor
      repository: library/$(repository)
      command: push
      tags: |
        $(version)-$(hash)
```

data.title: CacheV2: Unable to find pipeline caching scopes.
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug (essentially a reopen of #11869)

**Enter Task Name**: CacheV2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted
    - ubuntu-latest and Ubuntu16, agent version 2.173.0

## Issue Description
Same as #11869: when using the Cache task, I get the error "Unable to find pipeline caching scopes." (see logs below).

The pipeline is a pure YAML multi-stage pipeline. The problematic stage looks like this:

```yaml
stages:
  - stage: deploy_app
    displayName: Deploy app
    condition: and(succeeded(), or(eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/master'), eq(variables['DEPLOY'], 'true')))
    jobs:
      - deployment:
        displayName: Deploy
        environment: ${{ parameters.environment }}
        variables:
          - template: /infrastructure/azure-pipelines/state-secrets-variables.yaml
        strategy:
          runOnce:
            deploy:
              steps:
                - checkout: self
                - download: current
                  artifact: drop
[...]
                - task: Bash@3
                  displayName: Set npm_config_cache
                  inputs:
                    targetType: 'inline'
                    script: |
                      echo "##vso[task.setvariable variable=npm_config_cache]$(Pipeline.Workspace)/.npm"
                - task: Cache@2
                  displayName: Restore npm cache
                  inputs:
                    key: 'v2 | npm | "$(Agent.OS)" | infrastructure/package-lock.json'
                    path: '$(npm_config_cache)'
                    cacheHitVar: 'PULUMI_NODE_CACHE_RESTORED'
                  condition: and(succeeded(), ne(variables.PULUMI_NODE_CACHE_RESTORED, 'true'))
[...]
```

This issue first appeared after switching the `job` to a `deployment` job and adding an `environment`. 

While the Cache task is nested in a template multiple levels below, it does not fail on all pipelines that use the template. The directory structure is roughly as follows:
* /
  * ts-apps/
    * [...]/pipeline.yaml (these all work fine)
  * python-apps/
    * [...]/pipeline.yaml (these don't)
  * infrastructure/
    * azure-pipelines/
      * [...]
      * pulumi-command.yaml (this is the template that contains the Cache task and it's being used in all other pipelines)

### Task logs

data.title: Bad symlinks are not allowed in the cache directory
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: bug

**Enter Task Name**: Cache@2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

You can see it here for example: https://dev.azure.com/tinygo/tinygo/_build/results?buildId=1954&view=logs&j=ca395085-040a-526b-2ce8-bdc85f692774&t=bcb59787-fffd-4f14-b766-2e58e1ea8247


- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

Full output:

```
tarting: Cache LLVM source
==============================================================================
Task         : Cache
Description  : Cache files between runs
Version      : 2.0.1
Author       : Microsoft Corporation
Help         : https://aka.ms/pipeline-caching-docs
==============================================================================
Resolving key:
 - llvm-source-10-windows-v1 [string]
Resolved to: llvm-source-10-windows-v1
ApplicationInsightsTelemetrySender will correlate events with X-TFS-Session 3787af5f-e83c-4ee1-8085-ae7570df197d
Getting a pipeline cache artifact with one of the following fingerprints:
Fingerprint: `llvm-source-10-windows-v1`
There is a cache miss.
tar: ./libcxx/test/std/input.output/filesystems/Inputs/static_test_env/bad_symlink: File removed before we read it
ApplicationInsightsTelemetrySender correlated 1 events with X-TFS-Session 3787af5f-e83c-4ee1-8085-ae7570df197d
##[error]Process returned non-zero exit code: 1
Finishing: Cache LLVM source
```

The error is this line:

```
tar: ./libcxx/test/std/input.output/filesystems/Inputs/static_test_env/bad_symlink: File removed before we read it
```

I believe this matches [this StackOverflow entry](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56216397/file-removed-before-we-read-it). It appears that Cache@2 uses the `-h` flag to tar, which then chokes on an (intentionally) bad symlink. You can see the symlink here: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/release/10.x/libcxx/test/std/input.output/filesystems/Inputs/static_test_env/bad_symlink

### Task logs

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]

## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

### Error logs

[Insert error from the logs here for a quick overview]

data.title: Azure IoT Edge V2 - Deployment is not fetched by device
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: AzureIoTEdgeV2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    Azure pipelines

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    Hosted agent

## Issue Description

I'm not sure, whether this is a bug in the pipeline task or one in the IoT Hub. But I don't know where to report bugs in IoT Hub, so I'm reporting it here.
When the action `Deploy to IoT Edge devices` is executed, everything seems to be ok. Any existing deployment is overridden on the IoT Hub. But sometimes randomly the deployment is not assigned to the matching devices. In the device the _IoT Edge Runtime Response_ is **417 -- The device's deployment configuration is not set** and in the tab _Deployments_ there is no deployment assigned any more.

I figured out two workarounds which both involve manual actions:

- Delete the deployment on the IoT Hub before releasing a new one
- Edit the deployment (do dummy changes) and save it

In both cases the deployment get fetched by device.

data.title: JavaToolInstaller needs support for Service Connection certificate authentication
data.body:
The JavaToolInstaller task only supports a service connection with service principal key and not a certificate when retrieving the binaries from an Azure Storage blob container. 

Please consider adding this feature as for our organization and I imagine many other we have a requirement to harden the service principal authentication to only allow certificate authentication.  

## Issue Description
To reproduce this error create an Azure Resource Manager service connection with certificate authentication and one JavaToolInstaller task which retrieves the binaries from an Azure Storage location:

```
- task: JavaToolInstaller@0
  displayName: 'install java 11 from azure storage'
  inputs:
    versionSpec: '11'
    jdkArchitectureOption: 'x64'
    jdkSourceOption: AzureStorage
    azureResourceManagerEndpoint: ***
    azureStorageAccountName: ***
    azureContainerName: tools
    azureCommonVirtualFile: 'zulu11.37.17-ca-jdk11.0.6-linux_x64.tar.gz'
    jdkDestinationDirectory: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/jdk11'
    cleanDestinationDirectory: false

```
The error statement in the pipeline log is as follows (service principal id redacted): 
##[debug]Processed: ##vso[task.issue type=error;]Endpoint auth data not present: ***

The Azure Resource Group and the Packer Build tasks were fixed with this pull request: [11994](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/pull/11994). 

The same logic is missing form the following source file: [AzureStorageArtifactDownloader.ts](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/JavaToolInstallerV0/AzureStorageArtifacts/AzureStorageArtifactDownloader.ts)

### Error logs

```

Retrieving the JDK from Azure blob storage.

data.title: IIS Web App Manage (On machine group) | Adding bindings should be a graceful operation
data.body:
**WHEN** choosing the "Add binding" option in a "IIS web app manage" task
**IF** you have a binding that requires a certificate (https) and you have a thumbprint provided
**THEN** the first initial deployment will succeed
**THEN** all the consecutive ones will fail on the part where netsh is called in a similar manner:
`"netsh" http add sslcert ipport=0.0.0.0:443 certhash=*** appid={a78bae04-5ec5-4fc4-a879-c9fd8ba3ddb0} certstorename=MY`
**BECAUSE** the binding with the given certificate already exists

So currently you have to no if you are deploying a binding initially or not, and customize the deployment and only turn on/enable the add bindings part for the initial one or else it will fail.

I think it would be proper if given the error message _SSL Certificate add failed, Error: 183
Cannot create a file when that file already exists._ we shouldn't fail the task, and continue adding missing bindings if any or with execution of next task, but currently this fails a deployment.

- Server - Azure Pipelines (Releases, classic)
   
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 
UNIUN, UNIUN, Uniun Website, releaseId=1071&environmentId=2584


- Agent - **Hosted**:
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: **win-latest**

## Issue Description

When using the AzureCLIV1 or V2 task in a classic Release pipeline,
If using variables in the "inline script"
The variables aren't escaped according to the scripting environment being used.
See: https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/13161 for more detail.

This means, suppose you want to use a variable in the inline script, and it has been entered into devops and it may contain a special character (special as deemed by the scripting language used by the task, e.g batch script, powershell etc) - you have to create a second copy of that variable in devops, that is the "escaped" version of the same variable, and use that version in the inline script of this task. Otherwise the script will break.

This means you have to maintain two copies of such variables, and manually keep them in sync. This is not ideal. Is there a better way to solve this?

Perhaps you could add a "Escape variables?" option to the task, so that when this is checked, any variables uses in the inline script, will be escaped based on the rules of the target scripting language?

### Task logs

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]
See: https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/13161 for more detail.

## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

### Error logs
See: https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/13161 for more detail.

data.title: Azure Key Vault task converts %3B in secrets to ;
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: AzureKeyVault@1 (https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureKeyVaultV1)

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted, `windows-2019`

## Issue Description

The Azure Key Vault task is converting all instances of `%3B` in a secret to `;`.

To reproduce, create a secret in a key vault with `%3B` in the value somewhere. Use the Azure Key Vault task to download the secret and observe that all instances of `%3B` in the value are converted to `;`.

data.title: `DotNetCoreCLIV2` should respect `rollForward` in `global.json`

labels.name: backlog
labels.description: Work that is on the backlog and won't get marked stale

data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLIV2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?

Using Azure Pipelines but this isn't environment specific

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 

Using self hosted agents but this isn't environment specific

## Issue Description

When using `DotNetCoreCLIV2` and pulling the information from a `global.json` file, it's not considering [rollForward[(https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/global-json?tabs=netcore3x). 
Example, if specifying `"version": "3.1.100"`  with `"rollForward": "latestPatch"`, it should be able to install `3.1.106` (or whichever is the latest at that time)

It might be possible to do something similar using `3.1.x` as a version number, but that doesn't seem to be valid within `global.json`.

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug/Feature

**Enter Task Name**: NuGetAuthenticate

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises? Azure Pipelines
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: https://dev.azure.com/dnceng


- Agent - Hosted or Private: Both, it happens on all agents
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:

    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 

## Issue Description

The NuGetAuthenticate task doesn't honor the DOTNET_CLI_HOME environment variable. This variable is used by dotnet cli instead of HOME if it is defined, changing where dotnet cli loads nuget credential plugins from. This breaks authentication to private feeds because the NuGetAuthenticate task installed the credential provider into the HOME directory.

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]

Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

data.title: Python Twine Upload Authenticate problem when project contains space in name
data.body:
## Required Information
Question, Bug, or Feature?
Bug

**Enter Task Name**:  Python Twine Authenticate v0/v1

## Environment
Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description
Python Twine Upload Authenticate problem when project contains space in name
current pypirc file created is incompatible with twine.
twine splits index-servers on the space characters Azure project names with spaces result in trying to find
"project" and "name/feed"

I suggest an optional argument to manually set the section name for the index-servers in the .pypirc file 
This can also be used with twine -r

[distutils]
index-servers = project name/feed

[project name/feed]
repository = <first-repository URL>
username = <first-repository username>
password = <first-repository password>

### Task logs

python -m twine upload -r "example_feed" --config-file /home/vsts/work/_temp/twineAuthenticate/zMTT6I/.pypirc /home/vsts/work/1/s/dist/*
========================== Starting Command Output ===========================
/bin/bash --noprofile --norc /home/vsts/work/_temp/*********************************.sh
InvalidConfiguration: Missing 'project' section from the configuration file
or not a complete URL in --repository-url.
Maybe you have an out-dated '/home/vsts/work/_temp/twineAuthenticate/zMTT6I/.pypirc' format?
more info: https://packaging.python.org/specifications/pypirc/


## Troubleshooting
Example of .pypirc
at /home/vsts/work/_temp/twineAuthenticate/*****/.pypirc

data.title: https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/AzurePowerShellV5/InitializeAz.ps1 is missing support for "$endpointObject.authenticationType -ieq 'SPNCertificate'"
data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*:  Bug



**Enter Task Name**: here  
`AzurePowerShell@4`
`AzurePowerShell@5`

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/AzurePowerShellV4/InitializeAz.ps1
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/AzurePowerShellV5/InitializeAz.ps1

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

For service endpoints we are using `"authorization": {"scheme": "ServicePrincipal"` and `"authenticationType": "spnCertificate"`. When using `AzurePowerShell@4` or `AzurePowerShell@5` on anything other then `windows-latest` it seems support is missing for this authenticationtype, since it throws `"Only SPN credential auth scheme is supported for non windows agent."`. Looking at [InitializeAz.ps1](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/AzurePowerShellV5/InitializeAz.ps1) it only seems to try SPNKey;   

```
  try {
        if ($endpointObject.authenticationType -ieq 'SPNKey') {

```

data.title: [JavaToolInstallerV0] Default value for the "versionSpec" parameter
data.body:
## Required Information
**Question, Bug, or Feature?** 
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: JavaToolInstaller

## Issue Description
Since there were questions regarding which versions of JDK are available on Microsoft-hosted agents it makes sense to add a default value for `versionSpec` parameter if it's not specified by the user. The default value should contain the latest version of JDK that available at the moment. As an alternative print installed versions - if specified version not found as preinstalled.

Also, we can investigate the possibility replace "versionSpec" input field by the dropdown list with the actual versions of preinstalled JDK's.
